Message.Title: I love the Windows 8 Experience on my Acer laptop with touch screen
Message.Msg: Once you take the time to reinstall your programs, learn how to swipe the screen from the right, top bottom, etc and pin what you want to the screen it is a great experience. You can right click on anything control panel, outlook mail any website and choose pin to start. Then you simply drag the icon to where you want it on the screen. A quick swipe on the screen on the right brings up settings, devices and search. If you type control panel etc into search it comes right up and you can pin it to you big large screen. No start button because the whole screen becomes your start button. A simple click on the desktop and you have all the programs and another version of internet explorer. You have the old win 7 more or less without the start button that it takes a week to get over and then you will not want it. The experience is new, exciting and amazing with the touch screen. No one will ever go back after getting past the initial learning curve. Part of the curve is learning how to set the touch pad and touch screen. If you do not have that right than you are closing things by accident etc. If someone reviews this machine without learning how to use the machine than that persons review and publication are useless and should be avoided. A review of someone that does not know how to use the machine means the publication is a waste of time. Remember that. There is a definite small learning curve. The experience after that is fantastic. The manufacturers were slow to release touch screen machines which is need to enjoy the experience. They are moving at lightning speed all circuits go now. What do you think that means. Apple has dropped from 705 to 575 this year and straight down since the release of I phone 5. Google has gone down from 774 to 688. It is a sign of the times. It is irrelevant if Microsoft is not going up since the release date. It is the market itself and a sign consumers are not spending on anything. Iphone, droid or whatever. I also have Windows 8 phone using the Nokia Lumina 822. Another fantastic experience. If I dropped either machine and broke them I would buy another within 1 hour. I am 100% satisfied with Win 8. The Nokia has voice assisted turn by turn navigation. The camera is amazing, Win8 works flawlessly on the machine. I can run my business on the go now. I have 8 pop 3 email addresses on there and a windows 8 browser that actually works. So if there is a review from a guy that has been using an ipad for 5 years , and does not even learn how to use the machine it is irrelevant. Don't support the publications they write for and the critic will become irrelevant just like a review of a machine you try to use in 5 minutes without learning simple things like where the controls are. Window 8 is the future and watch how young people, students are reacting when they see the start screen. They want it and when there parents are ready to spend again it will take off like the next thing. Apple looks like old technology to me. Apple seems like 2009 and Microsoft feels new and exciting 2013 ish.

Topic.Title: Not sure why 'Tard Baldy keeps lying about tax rates

Message.Msg: LIAR! Historically, the term “tax rate” has meant the average or effective tax rate — that is, taxes as a share of income. The broadest measure of the tax rate is total federal revenues divided by the gross domestic product. By this measure, federal taxes are at their lowest level in more than 60 years. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that federal taxes would consume just 14.8 percent of G.D.P. this year. The last year in which revenues were lower was 1950, according to the Office of Management and Budget. The postwar annual average is about 18.5 percent of G.D.P. Revenues averaged 18.2 percent of G.D.P. during Ronald Reagan’s administration; the lowest percentage during that administration was 17.3 percent of G.D.P. in 1984. In short, by the broadest measure of the tax rate, the current level is unusually low and has been for some time. Revenues were 14.9 percent of G.D.P. in both 2009 and 2010.

Topic.Title: Special dividends, why does anyone want them?

Message.Msg: I'm well aware of creating your own dividend concept through stock sales but i think you are way over simplifying scenarios. It is clearly, way more complicated than theory. First - assuming all gains in portfolio, need to consider capital gains tax short term holdings vs long term holdings vs tax rate on special dividends. Then, nowadays, corporations have way too much cash on their balance sheet and declaring dividends are not going to drop their stock by theoretically dividend amount, if any at all... Costco is a good example - a large special dividend, and it went up by that amount? how do u figure? if Apple decides to divy out special dividends, it won't drop their price at all because they have too much cash on balance sheet to begin with and declaration of dividends could be seen as a shareholder friendly move.

Topic.Title: Special dividends, why does anyone want them?

Message.Msg: I agree, it is really stock by stock, case by case basis. In theory, you are 100% correct on creating your own dividend through stock sales. That costco special dividend situation is probably an exception as well - It declared $7 dividend at $95 and it shot up to 103 on the news.. so are the investors saying costco was $8 undervalued before because drag on cash balance? as it stands today, after ex-dividend, it should go back down to around $95... but that is the price when they declared the dividend to begin with???

Topic.Title: Stu-pid Moes like 'Tard Baldy measure rate versus GDP

Message.Msg: READ THIS YOU LYING SACK OF SCHITT. Corporate Profits Were the Highest on Record Last Quarter By CATHERINE RAMPELL Published: November 23, 2010 The nation’s workers may be struggling, but American companies just had their best quarter ever. The New York Times American businesses earned profits at an annual rate of $1.659 trillion in the third quarter, according to a Commerce Department report released Tuesday. That is the highest figure recorded since the government began keeping track over 60 years ago, at least in nominal or noninflation-adjusted terms.

Message.Title: The Tea Party Getting Tea Bagged
Message.Msg: Bloomberg Four Republicans who opposed Speaker John Boehner on spending and budget issues won’t return to the Budget or Financial Services committees when the next session of Congress begins in January, according to a House Republican leadership aide. The Republican Steering Committee removed Walter Jones of North Carolina and David Schweikert of Arizona from the Financial Services Committee, said the aide, who asked not to be named. Justin Amash of Michigan and Tim Huelskamp of Kansas were removed from the House Budget Committee, the aide said. Amash, Schweikert and Huelskamp were elected in 2010 with support of the Tea Party movement. Their reassignments drew a protest from FreedomWorks, an umbrella group for the Tea Party movement.

Message.Title: Republicans stripped of committee slots lash out at GOP leaders - EAT SCHITT GROVER
Message.Msg: Republicans stripped of committee slots lash out at GOP leaders A pair of House Republicans stripped of their plum committee assignments lashed out Tuesday at the GOP leadership, suggesting they were punished for insisting on fealty to conservative principles. Huelskamp and Amash, along with Reps. David Schweikert, R-Ariz., and Walter Jones, R-N.C., lost their seats on the budget panel and House Financial Services Committee after the GOP conference determined they were "not team players," in the words of one Republican aide. ************************************************************** #$%$ GROVER and grab some popcorn. Topic.Title: Win 8 tablets crash and burn

Message.Msg: Windows 8 is for tablets. It's not going to be an interface for all computers. HP Shopping is selling the same desktop computer under two different model numbers. One model number has Windows 8 and the other model number has Windows 7. The stock market journalists and analysts still don't understand the difference between a coffee-shop browser and a PC. Windows RT is not going well but there is a buzz about Atom Tablets. The Atom tablets are just not yet, very much in stock, but search for the Samsung ATIV 500T at $750 including optional keyboard.

Topic.Title: MS CEO

Message.Msg: No, SB has done exactly what the financial journalists and analysts wanted. Then when it doesn't work the blame is just continued. The mistake is in following the chorus that doesn't understand the difference between a coffee-shop browser and a PC. The mistake is in following marketing science and MBA science instead of computer science. All MS has to do is wait for Intel Atom and Intel Haswell to develop. Then have a touch operating system for tablets and a regular operating system for laptops and desktops. Of course there is Windows 8 Metro for mobile phones and tablets. It just looks so awful that I think the wrong design studio was chosen while the core operation can work. Another mistake is that the Surface that can't be used as a laptop but requires a desk top. Take a look at the form factor of the Samsung ATIV 500T. And I already mentioned a regular operating system for laptops and desktops. In fact HP Shopping is selling the same computer under two different model numbers. One model number is Windows 8 while the other model number is Windows 7. Go find another CEO and it's just yet another marketing and MBA person.
